headline: Giwa attack: Danmasanin Birnin-Gwari Kaduna laments loss of lives in agrarian communities
summarized_story:
The Danmasanin Birnin-Gwari, Zubair Abdurra’uf Idris, has described as saddening, the loss of lives in agrarian communities in Giwa and Birnin Gwari local government areas of Kaduna State.
In a statement, he said the communities of Kauran Fawa, Marke and Ruhiya of Idasu Ward of Giwa Local Government Area have suffered from untold killings and arson by bandits.
According to him, “let me register our heartfelt condolences to the people of Giwa Local Government Area over the cruel coordinated attack and killing of over thirty people by armed bandits.
“The loss of innocent lives particularly the agrarian rural communities due to bandits activities is saddening and worrisome in this particular era of insecurity in Giwa, Birnin-Gwari and other parts of Kaduna State and the North.

headline: Zamfara Gov, telecom networks dragged to court over network shutdown
summarized_story:
Zamfara Circle, a civil society organization, has dragged mobile telecommunications service providers, comprising MTN, GLO, Airtel and 9mobile, to court, demanding N100 million as damages for the deliberate shutdown of their services in the state.
The suit has Zamfara State Governor, Bello Matawalle, Commissioner for Justice and Attorney-General of the state, and the National Communications Commission (NCC) as co-defendants in the suit.
In the motion filed in a court in the state capital, the plaintiffs said the shutdown of the network has brought suffering and losses to the subscribers.
The motion was brought in pursuant to Order 15 Rule 3 (1) of the High Court of Zamfara State (Civil Procedure) Rules 2014, sections 96, 97, 98 and 99 of the Sherriff and civil process Act, Cap 551, LFL 2004 as well as the inherent jurisdiction of the court.
The group is praying for the court to determine among others, whether there exists between the plaintiffs and the 4th, 5th and 6th Defendants, a binding contract for the provision of telecommunication services including internet and email.

headline: Omicron: Jigawa rolls out COVID-19 booster vaccine doses
summarized_story:

Governor Badaru however commended the people of the state for accepting the vaccine.
He also urged the people of the state to ensure they take the vaccine and take the booster for those who have completed their doses to protect themselves from getting infected by the virus.

headline: Bandits seize N5m ransom bearer, 37 other abductees
summarized_story:
From John Adams, MinnaThe impunity by armed bandits in Niger State continued, on Sunday, when they held back a man who took N5 million ransom to them and demanded additional N1 million and motorcycles for his release and 30 others still in captivity.
The bandits, after much pleading by the community, agreed to collect N5 million ransom for the release of 55 people, including women and children abducted from Zagzaga community in Munya Local Government Area of the state, last month.
But, last Sunday night, the unexpected happened as no fewer than 19 of the captives escaped from the bandits dean, including the man who took the ransom to them, leaving about 37 still being held.
The village head also confirmed that 19 people, including the man who took the ransom to the bandits, miraculously escaped from the bandits last Sunday night, adding that despite that, the bandits insisted that N1 million must be paid.
This is in addition to the eight people, four men and four women, who had earlier escaped two weeks ago.

headline: Breaking: Buhari Writes National Assembly, Gives Reasons for Withholding Assent to Electoral Amendment Bill
summarized_story:
Tobi SoniyiPresident Muhammadu Buhari has withheld his assent to the Electoral Act (Amendment) Bill 2021.
In a letter to the Senate President, Ahmed Lawan, exclusively obtained by THISDAY, the president said that prevailing situation in the country would not allow him to sign the bill.
Among other reasons for rejecting the bill, the president cited high cost of conducting direct primaries, the security challenge of monitoring the election, violation of citizens’ rights and marginalization of small political parties.
The president said that it would be better to allow each political party to determine its mode of selecting candidates for election.

headline: Court Voids APC’s Participation in Anambra Guber Poll over Unlawful Primary
summarized_story:
Disqualifies Andy UbaAlex Enumah in AbujaJustice Inyang Ekwo of the Federal High court, Abuja on Monday voided the participation of the All Progressives Congress (APC) in the just concluded Anambra governorship election.
Justice Ekwo in a judgement held that the primary election of the APC that produced Senator Andy Uba as flag bearer of the party, substantially failed to comply with the electoral guidelines for the conduct of governorship primary election as well as the APC’s guidelines and constitution.

headline: Yahaya Bello Is The North Central Governor Who Made N60billion Cash Withdrawal From State Coffers–EFCC Sources

“In one of them, a governor in a North-Central state within the last six years (one individual) has withdrawn over N60 billion in cash.

headline: APC sets up convention sub-committee
summarized_story:
The ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) has commenced process leading to the national convention of the party.
To this end, the party has set up a sub-committees on budgeting and other relevant structures.
President Muhammadu Buhari had in November approved February 2022 as the tentative month for the national convention.

headline: 7,000 defects to PDP in Adamawa, APC confident of victory in 2023 -
summarized_story:
Adamawa State Governor, Ahmadu Umaru Fintiri has received over 7,000 members of the All Progressives Congress and Social Democratic Party to the Peoples Democratic Party in Jada Local Government Area of Adamawa State.
But, the All Progressives Congress in the state says it is confident of victory in the forthcoming 2023 general election.

headline: Oil Prices Steady as Omicron Worries Linger
summarized_story:
Oil prices steadied on Tuesday after a sharp fall in the previous session as investors worried about the rapid spread of the Omicron coronavirus variant and the impact of renewed restrictions on fuel demand.
Brent crude was down 8 cents, or 0.1%, at $71.44 a barrel by 0903 GMT, while U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 5 cents, or 0.1%, to $68.66 a barrel.
New Zealand delayed the planned reopening of its international border because of the sweeping spread of Omicron around the world on Tuesday, as several other countries reimposed social distancing measures.
Still, Moderna Inc said on Monday that a booster dose of its COVID-19 vaccine appeared to be protective against the fast-spreading Omicron variant in laboratory testing, providing some hope to investors.
In the United States, crude oil inventories were expected to have fallen for a fourth consecutive week, while distillate and gasoline stockpiles likely rose last week, a preliminary Reuters poll showed on Monday.

headline: Omicron’s Global Spread Prompts Renewed Lockdowns, Delayed Reopenings
summarized_story:
Omicron infections are multiplying rapidly across Europe, the United States and Asia, including in Japan where a single cluster at a military base has grown to at least 180 cases.
In the United States, officials said the variant claimed the life on Monday of an unvaccinated man in Texas after becoming the dominant strain in the country.
In Australia, where Omicron cases have surged but hospitalisations remain relatively low, Prime Minister Scott Morrison urged state and territory leaders to avoid further lockdowns.
The Omicron variant was first detected last month in southern Africa and Hong Kong and so far has been reported in at least 89 countries.
MARKET IMPACTThe rapid spread of the variant has ignited fears that more countries may impose economically disruptive restrictions, impacting markets.

headline: US to Be World’s Biggest LNG Exporter in 2022
summarized_story:
The United States is set to become the world’s biggest liquefied natural gas (LNG) exporter in 2022, surpassing Qatar and Australia, and may hold that title for years to come.
Much of that global appetite has been met by steadily rising U.S. LNG exports, which have reached new records every year since 2016 and is poised to continue in 2022.
The U.S. Energy Information Administration projects U.S. LNG exports will reach 11.5 billion cubic feet per day (bcfd) in 2022.
The United States should remain the biggest LNG exporter by capacity until around 2025, when Qatar could regain the lead as its North Field expansion starts to enter service.
But if some U.S. developers start building new LNG export plants, the United States may not give up the crown.

headline: OPEC+ Misses Oil Supply Target as Over-Compliance Hits 117% in November
summarized_story:
Compliance with oil production cuts by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and its allies known as OPEC+ stood at 117 per cent in November, up from 116 per cent the previous month.
Comparatively, the group remained 580,000 bpd below its 37.94 million bpd November production target, even though collective output rose by 410,000 bpd month on month.
The coalition would raise its output goal by 400,000 bpd to 38.34 million bpd this month, and by the same amount again to 38.74 million bpd in January.
The previous month, Nigeria had lost its Africa’s top oil producer status to the North African country, as its crude oil production continued to fall mainly due to ageing upstream infrastructure.
But in November, Nigeria pumped an additional 47,000 barrels per day when compared to the 1.228 million bpd produced averagely in the month of October 2021.
